segment.source: A quick overview of the networking technologies available for a UWP developer, with suggestions on how to choose the technologies that are right for your app.
segment.target: A quick overview of the networking technologies available for a UWP developer, with suggestions on how to choose the technologies that are right for your app.

segment.source: Which networking technology?'
segment.target: Which networking technology?'

segment.source: Which networking technology?
segment.target: Which networking technology?

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: A quick overview of the networking technologies available for a UWP developer, with suggestions on how to choose the technologies that are right for your app.
segment.target: A quick overview of the networking technologies available for a UWP developer, with suggestions on how to choose the technologies that are right for your app.

segment.source: Sockets
segment.target: Sockets

segment.source: Use Sockets when you are communicating with another device and want to use your own protocol.
segment.target: Use Sockets when you are communicating with another device and want to use your own protocol.

segment.source: Two implementations of sockets are available for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) developers: Windows.Networking.Sockets, and Winsock.
segment.target: Two implementations of sockets are available for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) developers: Windows.Networking.Sockets, and Winsock.

segment.source: If you are writing new code, then Windows.Networking.Sockets has the advantage of being a modern API, designed for use by UWP developers.
segment.target: If you are writing new code, then Windows.Networking.Sockets has the advantage of being a modern API, designed for use by UWP developers.

segment.source: If you are using cross-platform networking libraries or other existing Winsock code, or prefer the Winsock API, then use that.
segment.target: If you are using cross-platform networking libraries or other existing Winsock code, or prefer the Winsock API, then use that.

segment.source: When to use sockets
segment.target: When to use sockets

segment.source: Both sockets implementations enable you to communicate with other devices using protocols of your own choice, using TCP or UDP.
segment.target: Both sockets implementations enable you to communicate with other devices using protocols of your own choice, using TCP or UDP.

segment.source: Choose the sockets API that best meets your needs based on experience and any existing code you might be using.
segment.target: Choose the sockets API that best meets your needs based on experience and any existing code you might be using.

segment.source: When not to use sockets
segment.target: When not to use sockets

segment.source: Don't implement your own HTTP(S) stack using sockets.
segment.target: Don't implement your own HTTP(S) stack using sockets.

segment.source: Use HttpClient instead.
segment.target: Use HttpClient instead.

segment.source: If WebSockets (the StreamWebSocket and MessageWebSocket classes) meet your communications needs (TCP to/from a web server), consider using them rather than spend your own time and development resources implementing similar functionality with sockets.
segment.target: If WebSockets (the StreamWebSocket and MessageWebSocket classes) meet your communications needs (TCP to/from a web server), consider using them rather than spend your own time and development resources implementing similar functionality with sockets.

segment.source: Websockets
segment.target: Websockets

segment.source: The WebSockets protocol defines a mechanism for fast, secure two-way communication between a client and a server over the web.
segment.target: The WebSockets protocol defines a mechanism for fast, secure two-way communication between a client and a server over the web.

segment.source: Data is transferred immediately over a full-duplex single socket connection, allowing messages to be sent and received from both endpoints in real time.
segment.target: Data is transferred immediately over a full-duplex single socket connection, allowing messages to be sent and received from both endpoints in real time.

segment.source: WebSockets are ideal for use in real-time gaming where instant social network notifications and up-to-date displays of information (like game statistics ) need to be secure and use fast data transfer.
segment.target: WebSockets are ideal for use in real-time gaming where instant social network notifications and up-to-date displays of information (like game statistics ) need to be secure and use fast data transfer.

segment.source: UWP developers can use the StreamWebSocket and MessageWebSocket classes to connect with servers that support the Websocket protocol.
segment.target: UWP developers can use the StreamWebSocket and MessageWebSocket classes to connect with servers that support the Websocket protocol.

segment.source: When to use Websockets
segment.target: When to use Websockets

segment.source: When you want to send and receive data on an ongoing basis between a device and a server.
segment.target: When you want to send and receive data on an ongoing basis between a device and a server.

segment.source: When not to use Websockets
segment.target: When not to use Websockets

segment.source: If you are sending or receiving data infrequently, you might find it simpler to make individual HTTP requests from the device to the server, rather than establish and maintain a WebSocket connection.
segment.target: If you are sending or receiving data infrequently, you might find it simpler to make individual HTTP requests from the device to the server, rather than establish and maintain a WebSocket connection.

segment.source: WebSockets may not be suitable for very high-volume situations.
segment.target: WebSockets may not be suitable for very high-volume situations.

segment.source: Consider modeling your data flows and simulating your traffic through WebSockets before committing to using them in your design.
segment.target: Consider modeling your data flows and simulating your traffic through WebSockets before committing to using them in your design.

segment.source: HttpClient
segment.target: HttpClient

segment.source: Use HttpClient (and the rest of the Windows.Web.Http namespace API) when you are using HTTP(S) to communicate with a web service or a web server.
segment.target: Use HttpClient (and the rest of the Windows.Web.Http namespace API) when you are using HTTP(S) to communicate with a web service or a web server.

segment.source: When to use HttpClient
segment.target: When to use HttpClient

segment.source: When using HTTP(S) to communicate with web services.
segment.target: When using HTTP(S) to communicate with web services.

segment.source: When uploading or downloading a small number of smaller files.
segment.target: When uploading or downloading a small number of smaller files.

segment.source: If WebSockets (the StreamWebSocket and MessageWebSocket classes) meet your communications needs (TCP to/from a web server), and the web server in question supports WebSockets, consider using them rather than spend your own time and development resources implementing similar functionality with HttpClient.
segment.target: If WebSockets (the StreamWebSocket and MessageWebSocket classes) meet your communications needs (TCP to/from a web server), and the web server in question supports WebSockets, consider using them rather than spend your own time and development resources implementing similar functionality with HttpClient.

segment.source: When you are streaming content over the network.
segment.target: When you are streaming content over the network.

segment.source: When not to use HttpClient
segment.target: When not to use HttpClient

segment.source: If you are transferring large files, or large numbers of files, consider using background transfers instead.
segment.target: If you are transferring large files, or large numbers of files, consider using background transfers instead.

segment.source: If you want to be able to restrict upload/download limits based on connection type, or if you want to save progress and resume upload/download after an interruption, you must use background transfers.
segment.target: If you want to be able to restrict upload/download limits based on connection type, or if you want to save progress and resume upload/download after an interruption, you must use background transfers.

segment.source: If you are communicating between two devices and neither one is designed to act as an HTTP(S) server, you should use sockets.
segment.target: If you are communicating between two devices and neither one is designed to act as an HTTP(S) server, you should use sockets.

segment.source: Do not attempt to implement your own HTTP server and use HttpClient to communicate with it.
segment.target: Do not attempt to implement your own HTTP server and use HttpClient to communicate with it.

segment.source: Background transfers
segment.target: Background transfers

segment.source: Use the background transfer API when you want to reliably transfer files over the network.
segment.target: Use the background transfer API when you want to reliably transfer files over the network.

segment.source: The background transfer API provides advanced upload and download features that run in the background during app suspension and persist beyond app termination.
segment.target: The background transfer API provides advanced upload and download features that run in the background during app suspension and persist beyond app termination.

segment.source: The API monitors network status and automatically suspends and resumes transfers when connectivity is lost, and transfers are also Data Sense-aware and Battery Sense-aware, meaning that download activity adjusts based on your current connectivity and device battery status.
segment.target: The API monitors network status and automatically suspends and resumes transfers when connectivity is lost, and transfers are also Data Sense-aware and Battery Sense-aware, meaning that download activity adjusts based on your current connectivity and device battery status.

segment.source: These capabilities are essential when your app is running on mobile or battery-powered devices.
segment.target: These capabilities are essential when your app is running on mobile or battery-powered devices.

segment.source: The API is ideal for uploading and downloading large files using HTTP(S).
segment.target: The API is ideal for uploading and downloading large files using HTTP(S).

segment.source: FTP is also supported, but only for downloads.
segment.target: FTP is also supported, but only for downloads.

segment.source: A new background transfer feature in Windows 10 is the ability to trigger post-processing when a file transfer has completed, so that you can update local catalogs, activate other apps, or notify the user when a download is complete.
segment.target: A new background transfer feature in Windows 10 is the ability to trigger post-processing when a file transfer has completed, so that you can update local catalogs, activate other apps, or notify the user when a download is complete.

segment.source: When to use background transfers
segment.target: When to use background transfers

segment.source: Use background transfers to reliably transfer large files, or large numbers of files.
segment.target: Use background transfers to reliably transfer large files, or large numbers of files.

segment.source: Use background transfers with background transfer completion groups when you want to post-process file transfers with a background task.
segment.target: Use background transfers with background transfer completion groups when you want to post-process file transfers with a background task.

segment.source: Use background transfers if you want to be able to resume a transfer in progress after a network interruption.
segment.target: Use background transfers if you want to be able to resume a transfer in progress after a network interruption.

segment.source: Use background transfers if you want to be able to change transfer behavior based on network conditions like being on a metered data plan.
segment.target: Use background transfers if you want to be able to change transfer behavior based on network conditions like being on a metered data plan.

segment.source: When not to use background transfers
segment.target: When not to use background transfers

segment.source: If you are transferring a small number of small files, and you don't need to do any post-processing when the transfer is complete, consider using HttpClient PUT or POST methods.
segment.target: If you are transferring a small number of small files, and you don't need to do any post-processing when the transfer is complete, consider using HttpClient PUT or POST methods.

segment.source: If you want to stream data and use it locally as it arrives, use HttpClient.
segment.target: If you want to stream data and use it locally as it arrives, use HttpClient.

segment.source: Additional network-related technologies
segment.target: Additional network-related technologies

segment.source: Connection quality
segment.target: Connection quality

segment.source: The Windows.Networking.Connectivity API enables you to access network connectivity, cost, and usage information.
segment.target: The Windows.Networking.Connectivity API enables you to access network connectivity, cost, and usage information.

segment.source: For more information about using this API, see Accessing network connection state and managing network costs
segment.target: For more information about using this API, see Accessing network connection state and managing network costs

segment.source: DNS Service Discovery
segment.target: DNS Service Discovery

segment.source: The Windows.Networking.ServiceDiscovery.Dnssd API enables you to advertise a network service to other devices on the network using the DNS-SD protocol described in IETF RFC 2782.
segment.target: The Windows.Networking.ServiceDiscovery.Dnssd API enables you to advertise a network service to other devices on the network using the DNS-SD protocol described in IETF RFC 2782.

segment.source: Communicating over Bluetooth
segment.target: Communicating over Bluetooth

segment.source: Among other things, the Windows.Devices.Bluetooth API enables you to use Bluetooth to connect to other devices and transfer data.
segment.target: Among other things, the Windows.Devices.Bluetooth API enables you to use Bluetooth to connect to other devices and transfer data.

segment.source: For more information, see Send or receive files with RFCOMM.
segment.target: For more information, see Send or receive files with RFCOMM.

segment.source: Push notifications (WNS)
segment.target: Push notifications (WNS)

segment.source: The Windows.Networking.PushNotifications API enables you to use the Windows Notification Service (WNS) to receive push notifications over the network.
segment.target: The Windows.Networking.PushNotifications API enables you to use the Windows Notification Service (WNS) to receive push notifications over the network.

segment.source: For more information about using this API, see Windows Push Notification Services (WNS) overview
segment.target: For more information about using this API, see Windows Push Notification Services (WNS) overview

segment.source: Near field communications
segment.target: Near field communications

segment.source: The Windows.Networking.Proximity API enables you to use near-field communications for apps that use proximity or tap with devices to enable easy data transfer.
segment.target: The Windows.Networking.Proximity API enables you to use near-field communications for apps that use proximity or tap with devices to enable easy data transfer.

segment.source: For more information about using this API, see Supporting proximity and tapping.
segment.target: For more information about using this API, see Supporting proximity and tapping.

segment.source: RSS/Atom feeds
segment.target: RSS/Atom feeds

segment.source: The Windows.Web.Syndication API enables you to manage syndication feeds using RSS and Atom formats.
segment.target: The Windows.Web.Syndication API enables you to manage syndication feeds using RSS and Atom formats.

segment.source: For more information about using this API, see RSS/Atom feeds.
segment.target: For more information about using this API, see RSS/Atom feeds.

segment.source: Wi-Fi enumeration and connection control
segment.target: Wi-Fi enumeration and connection control

segment.source: The Windows.Devices.WiFi API enables you to enumerate Wi-Fi adapters, scan for available Wi-Fi networks, and connect an adapter to a network.
segment.target: The Windows.Devices.WiFi API enables you to enumerate Wi-Fi adapters, scan for available Wi-Fi networks, and connect an adapter to a network.

segment.source: Radio control
segment.target: Radio control

segment.source: The Windows.Devices.Radios API allows you to find and control radios on the local device, including Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.
segment.target: The Windows.Devices.Radios API allows you to find and control radios on the local device, including Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.

segment.source: Wi-Fi Direct
segment.target: Wi-Fi Direct

segment.source: The Windows.Devices.WiFiDirect API allows you to connect and communicate with other local devices using Wi-Fi Direct to create ad-hoc local wireless networks.
segment.target: The Windows.Devices.WiFiDirect API allows you to connect and communicate with other local devices using Wi-Fi Direct to create ad-hoc local wireless networks.

segment.source: Wi-Fi Direct services
segment.target: Wi-Fi Direct services

segment.source: The Windows.Devices.WiFiDirect.Services API enables you to provide Wi-Fi Direct services and connect to them.
segment.target: The Windows.Devices.WiFiDirect.Services API enables you to provide Wi-Fi Direct services and connect to them.

segment.source: Wi-Fi Direct Services are the way that one device on a Wi-Fi direct ad-hoc network (a Service Advertiser) offers capabilities to another device (a Service Seeker) over a Wi-Fi Direct connection.
segment.target: Wi-Fi Direct Services are the way that one device on a Wi-Fi direct ad-hoc network (a Service Advertiser) offers capabilities to another device (a Service Seeker) over a Wi-Fi Direct connection.

segment.source: Mobile operators
segment.target: Mobile operators

segment.source: Windows 10 exposes to a wide developer audience some APIs that have previously only been exposed to device manufacturers and mobile operators.
segment.target: Windows 10 exposes to a wide developer audience some APIs that have previously only been exposed to device manufacturers and mobile operators.

segment.source: Note that while these APIs are exposed now, they are also gated by specific app capabilities that must be approved by Microsoft before an app can be published.
segment.target: Note that while these APIs are exposed now, they are also gated by specific app capabilities that must be approved by Microsoft before an app can be published.

segment.source: Actual use of these APIs will still be limited primarily to device manufacturers and mobile operators.
segment.target: Actual use of these APIs will still be limited primarily to device manufacturers and mobile operators.

segment.source: Network operations
segment.target: Network operations

segment.source: The Windows.Networking.NetworkOperators API deals primarily with the configuration and provisioning of phones.
segment.target: The Windows.Networking.NetworkOperators API deals primarily with the configuration and provisioning of phones.

segment.source: As such, permission to use the capabilities that control it are limited to device manufacturers and telecom providers.
segment.target: As such, permission to use the capabilities that control it are limited to device manufacturers and telecom providers.

segment.source: SMS
segment.target: SMS

segment.source: The Windows.Devices.Sms namespace deals with SMS and related messages as low-level entities.
segment.target: The Windows.Devices.Sms namespace deals with SMS and related messages as low-level entities.

segment.source: It is provided for use by mobile operators for app-directed SMS use, and is controlled by a capability that will not be approved for use by most app developers.
segment.target: It is provided for use by mobile operators for app-directed SMS use, and is controlled by a capability that will not be approved for use by most app developers.

segment.source: If you are writing an app to deal with messages, you should use the Windows.ApplicationModel.Chat API instead, as it is designed to handle not just SMS messages, but also messages from other sources such as realtime chat apps, enabling a much richer chat/messaging experience.
segment.target: If you are writing an app to deal with messages, you should use the Windows.ApplicationModel.Chat API instead, as it is designed to handle not just SMS messages, but also messages from other sources such as realtime chat apps, enabling a much richer chat/messaging experience.
